reviews.text: This is a classic grand old hotel of the pre-Castro era. Pictures of movie stars and political leaders who visited the hotel are in all the public areas, and the hotel reeks of class. That it is in communist Cuba, and is owned by the Cuban government in partnership with a Spanish company is still tough to reconcile. I know it's a tourist cash-cow, but still, it just doesn't fit in any way with a communist government.
reviews.title: Great location, alternate reality

reviews.text: Moving on...the rooms are old, but just fine. There is carpeting. We had two twin beds (would have preferred one larger bed). As an old property, the rooms aren't the same, so friends we travelled with had, by luck, a larger room with a better view. Still, ours was fine.
reviews.title: The Historic Hotel !!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The room honor bar list did not include the in room coffee, and it wasn't listed as a billed item anywhere. However, when we checked out we were charged for the in room coffee. The cost was 1 CUC a day - not a lot, but I resent that there was any charge without some notice. There is also a charge for use of the room safe.
reviews.title: A dignified old lady

reviews.text: Public areas are grand, and I felt classiest sitting in the large chairs/sofas of the outside bar, just out back of the hotel. (Since there are several areas, specifying which makes sense.)
reviews.title: Old Charm and History

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Malecon is right there with the ocean beyond. That was a treat - at the end of the day we joined in the parade of Cubans gathering along the Malecon.
reviews.title: Disappointing stay

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Our travel agent booked us in here for an overnight stay before our next day transfers to Trinidad. We were disappointed that the stay was so short.
reviews.title: A really funky place to stay in Havana

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The hotel has fantastic old world atmosphere about it and feels as though it hasn't changed since the 1940's. Having said that, it is well maintained. There is a great outdoor garden and bar area.
reviews.title: Elegant, historic hotel with excellent facilities

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The rooms were well equipped and very comfortable. The service and breakfast was ordinary, but hey, it's Cuba and all par for the course!
reviews.title: Very good 2 night stay

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Even if you don't stay at the hotel it is certainly worth a visit to see.
reviews.title: And Oldie But A (Mostly) Goodie

reviews.text: This hotel has everything that we require in a holiday hotel. It is a beautiful and historic building with extremely comfortable and quiet rooms. The cuisine is good, the staff helpful and friendly and it is important not to miss the free history tour (watch out for the letter boxes on each floor) and the the free entrance to the amazing Parisien cabaret. We wish that we could have stayed longer here and if we ever come back to Cuba, this is where we will stay.
reviews.title: Havana - Experience an aging grand old hotel

reviews.text: This impressive and historic hotel is lovely, with a decor out of the past. The public areas (the only areas I saw) were beautifully kept up. But take care with their show - we paid a high CUC charge to enter and see the show, sat down, and were handed a menu for dinner and drinks. When asked repeatedly (in English and in Spanish) if the dinner was included with the show, we were told yes. At the end of the show we were presented with a bill that caused us to pay another high CUC charge for our dinners.
reviews.title: Beautiful hotel, but keep aware!

reviews.text: I stayed here in Dec 2011 - a large imposing hotel with a lot of history. The rooms are basic but have good flat screen TVs and inexpensive mini-bars. The garden is lovely with peacocks wandering around. The breakfast buffet offers a great selection as well. I didn't go to any of the restaurants though as they were quite expensive compared to the trendier restaurants in Havana.
reviews.title: A Unique Experience

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: spent some nights in this beautiful hotel in havanna........ just to sit in the bar and look at all the selebrites who`s been there..exellent service & ok food(cuba wise), this was our 2 nd time to cuba and yes... nothing has happend for ten years..for what thats worth..cubans are really nice people and i would recommand to spend a night or 2 in hemningways hotel in central havanna.we also went on a full day excursion with a catamaran with all.incl wery nice.. do that..the standard in cuba is so so. but they keep it nice and clean,,thumbs up....
reviews.title: time bandits

reviews.text: The hotel reeks of the past. The fact that the rooms are simple (but clean) and the mechanical systems (plumbing, electrical and a/c) temperrmental reveals how few improvements have been done to the hotel. But that also means that the floors are original, the tile work gorgeous and the outside veranda the place to hang out. The hotel oozes atmosphere.
reviews.title: Average accomodations but wonderful atmosphere

reviews.text: For history and appearances, it couldn't be be better. But the staff varies from friendly and helpful to abrupt and distant. The room we had was fine, although we needed help with a loud A/C noise, which we got.
reviews.title: OK, but could be better

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed here for 3 nights from 1st January. We paid £127GBP a night and booked independently through Hotelopia. We booked late and peak season so were restricted to where we could stay and had our hearts set on one with a pool (the weather was very windy and quite chilly so we only used it once, however.)
reviews.title: Big impersonal hotel we liked but not loved

reviews.text: I have been to Cuba before so understand the culture a little. I feel that this may be a national treasure of a hotel and by Cuban standards it is very grand but by world standards it is nothing like a 5 star hotel, so please be aware of this if you have never been to Cuba and adjust your expectations accordingly.
reviews.title: You won't want to leave. Best Daiquiris in Havana in the Churchill Bar

reviews.text: Good points:
reviews.title: Amazing colonial architecture

reviews.text: -Breakfast is extensive - not everything is good quality but considering it is Cuba it is good - delicious omelettes made in front of you, soft croissants, rolls and pastries, fresh orange juice from a squeezing machine.
reviews.title: A Moment in Time ...

reviews.text: -Swimming pools good - shame we only used one once as it was very windy and too cold when we were there.
reviews.title: Hotel Nacional- Old world charm and service

reviews.text: If walls had ears the Hotel Nacional in Havana would have a few stories to tell. The movie star bar is wallpapered with famous visitors like Ava Gardner and Frank Sinatra who were regulars during the Mafia's Havana years. The poisoning scene in Graham Greene's Our Man in Havana is set in the hotel's restaurant.
reviews.title: Magical Mafia Hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Sitting on the terrace drinking mojitos reminds me of that line in the book, 'Isn't it wonderful the way you always get what you pray for?'
reviews.title: Step back in time

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: There are some bad tempered peacocks loitering in the garden and one guest allegedly had a scorpion in his safe. But that aside, this atmospheric place is perfect even the fleas dancing in the rotting upholstery when it rains have some charm.
reviews.title: A Piece of History

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The amazing, grand and atmospheric foyer of the Hotel Nacional was our first introduction to Cuba. Not quite what we expected but very impressive. Arriving late in the evening we were pleasantly surprised that the cafe was still open - we had 2 mijitos (of course!) and 2 large delicious pasta dishes for $20 which we felt was very reasonable. The staff were very pleasant and helpful. We only stayed one night but could have happily have spent more time there.
reviews.title: Aging, but still a classic

reviews.text: Stayed 4 nights here in February 13 as part of a 2 centre holiday. Location wise its a 5-10 CUC taxi to old Havana and there is not much around the hotel for the general tourist. That said the hotel has a real historic feel about it and takes a great photo. We had a great sea view in a room that was clean and reasonably spacious but wouldn't be described as either pristine or up to date. Thats the trade off of having real character versus a modern up to date hotel. We ate breakfast at the hotel (good job as nowhere around to eat) and it was more than adequate. The snack bar in the evening also did a reasonable burger or pizza. Seeing the old american cars around the hotel and getting a ride into old Havana waas great and worth the extra 5 CUC for the photos and experience. Its a good walk along the Melacon (sea wall promenade) and great for a jog if you are in to that. There is a real hussle and bussle vibe around the hotel. Staff were mixed but have to say generally sullen compared to the hotel on the coast which probably the difference between this which is government owned and the customer training given by the big hotel chains. Speaking to other holiday makers who stayed at the Anglatere (other historic hotel) it seemed that we had a better hotel with a less central location and they got the more shabby place but one that is in the centre. As always there is a trade off. Overall as long as you have reasonable expectations of a place you should not be disappointed and should come away with some great photos and the memory of staying at the hotel of the rich and famous.
reviews.title: Great meals in the cafe

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The hotel was great. The staff, rooms, food, and ambiance of this hotel were superb. The hotel is on a large piece of property on the Malecon, offering great views of the roadway and water.
reviews.title: Great Hotel - Decent Location

reviews.text: My only issue with the hotel is that it is 2 miles from Old Havana. While we did walk from Old Havana to the hotel once, a taxi will most likely be required (which should cost 5 CUC from Old Havana to the Hotel Nacional).
reviews.title: Historical gem

reviews.text: I stayed here at the end of November 2011. We were upgraded to this hotel from the Sevilla because a room was not available due to renovations going on at the Sevilla. Pretty good upgrade. But the location, although very good, was not near our comrades that we were going to associate with. Long, but pleasant walk to downtown and the Capitol. Cabs are cheap though.
reviews.title: only a Historical Hotel

reviews.text: My room was small but very well appointed and clean. The towels were thick and fluffy. The pillows on the bed were rather flat and underfilled, but I had heard of this problem in Cuba and brought my own pillow anyway, so no problems there.
reviews.title: Excellent location and very friendly staff

reviews.text: I especially loved the historical nature of the hotel. Tremendous amount of charm. The grounds are very well manintained. The outdoor lounge was a great place to have a nightcap before retiring, or just to hang out. Big comfy chairs. Good mojitos.
reviews.title: We got lucky!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I stayed in this iconic hotel with my husband for 3 nights on arrival for our first trip to Cuba.
reviews.title: step back in time

reviews.text: I had been expecting traditional Art Decco and was slightly disappointed on check in, however, one night's sleep in very comfortable beds, and I saw the hotel for what it is.
reviews.title: A very enjoyable stay

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Nacional is a Grande Dame of a hotel, with many original 1930 features and decor.
reviews.title: A MUST in Havana!

reviews.text: Our room was excellant, 6th floor facing the rear of the hotel overlooking the terrace and sea.
reviews.title: Hotel Nacional de Cuba

reviews.text: Beds were extremely comfortable, room large with dual aspect, bathroom perfectly acceptable although would have preferred a walk in shower.
reviews.title: A must-stay hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This was my first trip to Cuba, so to do it legally as an American, I was part of a "people to people" sanctioned tour. We arrived a day ahead of the rest of the group, so needed to book an extra night. We got a corner suite with view over the Malecón and the Gulf of Mexico to the north. It was one of the "historic rooms" named after a person of note who had stayed there. Our personage was the discoverer of penicillin, which we thought was pretty funny.
reviews.title: Glad I stayed here for my first visit

reviews.text: The bedroom and bathroom were both spacious with a separate sitting room with extra TV that could also be shared with the other adjoining bedroom for families or couples traveling together. The twin beds were surprisingly comfortable, and the air conditioning worked well. The bathroom had both an enclosed shower with multiple shower heads as well as a bathtub with shower. The shower heads leaked badly in the stall, so we mostly used the one in the tub. The toilet was also slow to flush and occasionally emitted sewer gas odors.
reviews.title: Havana's Best!

reviews.text: There was a well-stocked mini-bar and a closet safe that did not work--so we locked valuables in our luggage. The TV included both local and U.S. cable fare, including CNN. The floor maids were friendly and left cute notes in broken English wishing us a good stay... to be sure we left a tip. I don't begrudge the focus on tips, since they are very dependent of money from tourists, which is a separate currency from what they are paid in, which lacks significant value from CUCs (the currency which tourists use).
reviews.title: Havana historical hotel

reviews.text: The desk staff lack any semblance of charm or service, and it seems to take three people to process any transaction. Depending on time of day (or mood?) you may or may not be able to exchange money at the main desk, sometimes being referred to a basement exchange office. And sometimes they set a limit on how much money you can exchange. (The exchange offices at the airport also all ran out of available cash when we arrived on a later Air Canada flight, which was a bit unnerving.)
reviews.title: Time Warp at the Hotel Nacional

reviews.text: The Nacional has lots of historic charm, some of it in better shape than other parts. We had no time to use the two swimming pools, which were certainly being enjoyed by others. A nice feature of the hotel is the sprawling grounds and gardens with tables and bars overlooking the Malecón, where local people gather to socialize in the evenings. It's also quite enjoyable to savor a rum drink in the large wicker chairs that line the covered veranda behind the hotel (although you are likely to share the space with cigar smokers as well). The included breakfast buffet is fine with enough variety to satisfy most guests. Other meals in the hotel were just OK with a cinema-themed cafe serving serviceable burgers and pizza 24 hours in the basement.
reviews.title: Great historic hotel - bad service
